awd_titl_txt: The Gauged Linear Sigma Model and Its Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
During the past twenty years, there has been a great deal of interaction between mathematics and physics. Various models from physics have had great impact on mathematics. One of these models is the gauged linear sigma model. This project includes a comprehensive program to study the mathematical theory of the gauged linear sigma model and its applications. The project is interdisciplinary in nature, and both physical and mathematical ideas play essential roles. It adds to the current trend of interaction between mathematics and physics. The project will also  enhance the training of undergraduate and graduate students, as well as postdoctoral fellows.

Building on the PI's initial success on algebraic geometric theory of gauged linear sigma model, this project will construct log gauged linear sigma model moduli space. The new theory has a range of applications including  some well-known problems such as the computation of the higher genus Gromov-Witten theory of compact Calabi-Yau 3-folds.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor

por.por_cntn:
Enumerative geometry is a subbranch of algebraic geometry that studies questions about counting algebraic objects in a geometric setting. This has been an active area of research ever since Witten's foundational papers in the 1990s, and it continues to benefit greatly from connections with string theory and theoretical physics, which provide a rich source of interesting conjectures. The gauged linear sigma model (GLSM) is a model originally considered in physics that has since been interpreted mathematically in various ways. Mathematically, a model like this is represented by a moduli space - a geometric space whose points parametrize curves or other mathematical objects - and new moduli spaces yield new counting formulas via equivariant localization. The goal of this project was to further develop this mathematical theory and apply it to various questions in enumerative geometry, including Witten's r-spin class and higher genus Gromov-Witten invariants.

This grant supported the research of the former and current PIs, as well as enhancing the training of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in this area. The former PI and his collaborators wrote several papers developing the general theory of the "Logarithmic GLSM" moduli space and then applying it to compute new higher genus invariants of the quintic three-fold. The grant also supported the current PI's ongoing work on the "Logarithmic double ramification cycle", a related topic in enumerative geometry.


Last Modified: 05/15/2022
Modified by: Aaron Pixton
